intro: Sinapis burmanni, commonly known as Burmann's mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other mustard plants. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has pinnately divided leaves. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, typical of the mustard family. The seeds are small and contained within siliques, which are elongated pods characteristic of the Brassicaceae family.
